thread.title_full: Vandal breaks glass doors at Islamic Center of Fort Collins, throws bible in prayer room

author: Jesse Paul
title: Vandal breaks glass doors at Islamic Center of Fort Collins, throws bible in prayer room

organizations.name: islamic center of fort collins tawfik aboellail

text:
A vandal struck the Islamic Center of Fort Collins early Sunday, throwing rocks through windows and tossing a Bible into the building’s prayer room.
The incident, which forced the cancellation Sunday of religious classes for children, drew quick condemnation from anti-hate groups, Fort Collins Police Chief John Hutton and U.S. Rep. Jared Polis.
Hutton called the vandalism “unacceptable,” and he urged anyone with information on the crime to come forward. Polis said “it’s time for us to stand in unity. These acts must end.”
Unacceptable! I urge anyone who has information about this incident to come forward and help us solve this crime. @FCPolice @FCCrimeStopper 
— John Hutto (@FCPSChief) March 26, 2017 

The vandalism that occurred at the Islamic Center in Ft. Collins is unacceptable. It’s time for us to stand in unity. These acts must end.
— Rep. Jared Polis (@RepJaredPolis) March 26, 2017 

The center said on Facebook that the vandal, a young man, broke the building’s back door at about 4 a.m. and inflicted “quite a bit of damage.” No injuries were reported.
“I think the perpetrator is a young man, probably in his late 20s or early 30s, very strong,” said Tawfik Aboellail, president of the center. “He tried to break in using a screwdriver, kicking at the door. Finally he broke two back doors with five-pound rocks.”
Aboellail said, “Thank God no one was here.”
“The Bible being thrown into the prayer hall is a message in itself,” Aboellail said. “We are peaceful people. We love our Christian and Jewish brothers. We don’t have any problems with anyone.”
President of the Islamic Center of Fort Collins Tawfik AboEllail on the extent of the damage. Happened around 4 a.m. pic.twitter.com/93CRaN0Q6M 
— Cassa Niedringhaus (@CassaMN) March 26, 2017 

Although the man didn’t make his way into the center, he threw a large rock into its prayer room, scratching some woodwork.
The center, which mostly served students from nearby Colorado State University, plans to ask local authorities for help in keeping the center safe.

“Something needs to be done, basically,” Aboellail said. “Nobody is safe anymore. It could happen to anybody.”
A Fort Collins police representative did not return a message seeking comment Sunday. A rally, organized by Fort Collins religious leaders, was scheduled for 5 p.m. Sunday to show support for the center.
